instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, no fan spin
threads.message: have another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with green light and no fan spin this time. no sign of liquid damage. initially PRAM reset worked but then it died again. already checked around ISL and pins 17/18 etc. and have normal values (low resistance)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, no fan spin
threads.message:
Use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads for that.
I prefer to solder a tiny wire on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and simulate power button touching some metal plate from chassis...
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> must react then. <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> should be high, of course.
Check if PCH receives 32KHz oscillation.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, no fan spin
threads.message:
Hmm i think SMC on/off is doing nothing. am not getting anything on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  on <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> it's always 3.3

How would I check PCH for oscillation? im a noob! haha

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, no fan spin
threads.message:
Yes, check now if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL>/4/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL> react too.
Use o-scope, or repeatedly trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> if use DC multimeter only.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, no fan spin
threads.message: Ok so the S4 sometimes i catch the multimeter going up to 0.025v when triggering just for a second s3 does nothing it appears I think. and neither does s5. something interesting I found accidentally. when triggering power press once, I was accidentally measuring <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and it was pulsing from 0v to 3.3 v constantly until it was eventually stable at 3v. not sure if relevant

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, no fan spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> should be high before board starts; depends by <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
SMC generates <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> in base of it.
The sleep reactions should be ordered as S5 -> S4 -> S3.
If <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts, no sleep reaction will point to PCH.
But you must be sure if no reaction at all.
Catch a cheap analog second hand o-scope; it is good enough for this job.
I don't recommend mini DSO bullshits...
You must also assure PCH gets all necessary signals to power on.

threads.message: Which is the PCH? I can see many different ones on the schematic? Do you think it's fixable with Osciliscope and patience?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, no fan spin
threads.message:
I think i have good news! i soldered a bigger wire to <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> are consistently responding to rapid triggering s5 goes to 0.002 and s4 goes to 0.03 consistently.

However <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> is not responding at all. it's dead

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, no fan spin
threads.message:
On DC scale you must get more than 1V, normally more than 2V pulse when trigger it...
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts with drop pulse close to 0V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, no fan spin
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts and drops from 3.4v to 0.3v. is that close enough?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, no fan spin
threads.message: That's good, but you must get more evident reaction at sleep signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, no fan spin

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, no fan spin
threads.message: If you cannot confirm sleep reaction, start checking basic signals for PCH.
